title: How do I build up my state pension after retiring early due to ill health?
text:
I left the NHS five and half years ago and was allowed to claim my NHS pension early at 50.

However, I wasn't informed that I had to send my sick notes in to the pensions department to continue to build up my state pension contributions.

I had never been absent from work before and have never claimed state benefits.

NHS worker: I retired early due to ill health, so how do I carry on building up my state pension? (Stock image)

My GP has told me that he would be willing to provide evidence of sickness and ill health but I am having great difficulty finding who and where to send these notes and evidence to.

I have tried every phone number I can find only to be disconnected or stuck in a loop not being able to state which benefit I require.

I am not a benefit claimer. Since finishing work my husband has supported me so I have no record at a job centre and having contacted them by phone they told me they could do nothing for me.

I would therefore be extremely grateful if you could help or at least point me in the right direction.

SCROLL DOWN TO FIND OUT HOW TO ASK YOUR PENSION QUESTION

Steve Webb replies: As you are aware, even for years when you didn't actually pay National Insurance Contributions (NICs) you can still be 'credited' in to the system in certain circumstances, and this helps to protect your state pension record.

Unfortunately, simply being signed off work by your GP is not enough on its own to trigger entitlement to credits.

Steve Webb: Find out how to ask the former Pensions Minister a question about your retirement savings in the box below

The way that National Insurance credits work for those who are unable to contribute because of unemployment or sickness is that they are triggered by qualifying for the relevant National Insurance benefit.

For example, people who are unemployed and are entitled to Jobseekers Allowance (JSA) or who are off sick and entitled to Employment Support Allowance (ESA) automatically get credits towards their state pension.

Focusing on ESA, there are two version of this benefit – 'contributory' ESA for those with a recent record of paying NICs, and 'income-based' ESA for those with a low household income.

It sounds as though you would not qualify for either of these.

You probably would not get 'contributory' ESA because of your lack of recent NI contributions, and I'm assuming you would not get 'income-based' ESA because of your husband's income.

However, there is a third route and this is called 'credits only'. What you would need to do is claim ESA, even though you know you will not get weekly benefit.

As long as you satisfy the other tests (eg satisfying them that you are not fit for work) then you should qualify for credits towards your state pension. Hundreds of thousands of people are in exactly this position.

There are however strict time limits on claims, so if you make one now the most it could be backdated by is three months.

You should be aware however that if you do put in a claim for 'credits only' ESA, you still have to jump through all the same hoops as other claimants who do get weekly benefit, including attending periodic medical assessments.

If you do not wish to do this then your main option to protect your state pension would be to consider making voluntary NI contributions.

If you and your husband have some savings then these could be used to top up your NI record.

A year of voluntary contributions currently costs a lump sum of £780, and this would boost your final state pension by around £250 per year, assuming you would not otherwise get a full state pension. I have written a guide to state pension top-ups which you can find here.

I have assumed throughout that you were not receiving child benefit for a child under 12 in any of the years that we are talking about.

If you were, then the good news is that you automatically get NI credits for those years.
